comments.commentBody: Looking at Jong and thinking about Trump, it's comforting to realize what a miraculous thing evolution is, especially when it comes to selecting leaders.
Offer Kim Jong-un a lifetime membership to Mar-a-Lago and it will work out.
Sweden basks under our nuclear umbrella.

Historically (the last 40 years) the US/North Korea negotiations seem to fall into the same pattern. We make an agreement and the North starts development of weapons systems again. Then a period of combative behavior, followed by another agreement.

The bottom line is that the Kim family will never give up the only threat they have (nuclear) to stay in power by the US alone.

The US needs to stop working directly with N Korea as it won't solve the issue of safely on the peninsula.

China is the key to solving this situation...and China needs to be incentivized to help. President Trump (who seems bold enough to suggest it) needs to threaten to place nuclear weapons in Japan and South Korea as a deterrent to the North.

This would force China's hand into the removal of the North Korean weapons program as they certainly don't want the whole region weaponized.

The PRC has cut off tourism to South Korea and halted the influx of Korean entertainment to China, as punishment, because of the deployment of the THAAD anti-missile system in South Korea.
The leadership in China is likely going to help make war a reality before they actually get around to doing something about the DPRK – their sponsored poster child for war.
I do hope there are many more more techniques to combat enemies that are not discussed in public newspapers
So you're saying that this problem just magically happened in the last week?
We can only hope that sounder minds in our government prevail. We are walking a tactical tightrope; we need leadership, not tweets.
What to do about Africa?
leave it alone !!!!!
Stop buying oil there and stop selling guns and weapons there.
To leave it to Africans !

This is another example that funding rebel groups, and constructing countries fails drastically. What the United States did by supporting the division of The Sudan despite all signs that a group of rebels who have been fighting for the past 50 years will bring nothing but wrath on the people they claim they have been fighting for.

Africa needs unity, not division, but what can we do with the alleged "Moral Superiority" of the "West", the immaturity, the inability to face its past, the addiction to power and control.

The problem here is not the AU, it's not the dictatorship in Northern Sudan, it's not can South Sudan rule itself, the problem, is that a civilization that lives so far, that is so ignorant about it self, and definitely about the world, assumes that its so superior in values, in success, without even looking at its own history, and present in dealing with Africans.

It's so sad, that a group of elites in this civilization, can mobilize this amount of wealth, and power to the misery of the most vulnerable people on earth, from ... - it's meaning less to count the mistakes - it's so exhausting as a human being living in one of these countries to know that my future, and the future of my kids is run by people who neglect to look at there own life and assume that they are better, So much for FREEDOM , the FAKE freedom I say , your illusion of Freedom.
As you president say : SAD SAD SAD
"the generosity from the West" , WOW
Who gave the oil money to the rich people? My guess: Western oil companies.
Wrong.  China, India, Malaysia.  The US has imposed sanctions on South Sudan oil companies.
Wrong again, the US has imposed sanctions on North Sudan government, not South Sudan government, which is the repel group funded by US governments for decades.
The hat is from Kerry.

From the International Rescue Committee's website: www.rescue.org/article/lost-boys-sudan: "In 1987, civil war drove an estimated 20,000 young boys from their families and villages in southern Sudan. Most just six or seven years old, they fled to Ethiopia to escape death or induction into the northern army. They walked more than a thousand miles, half of them dying before reaching Kakuma refugee camp in Kenya. The survivors of this tragic exodus became known as the Lost Boys of Sudan."

"In 2001, close to four thousand Lost Boys came to the United States seeking peace, freedom and education. The International Rescue Committee helped hundreds of them to start new lives in cities across the country."

I have been and remain a part of a group of individuals in the Boston area that has and continues to mentor a number of the "Lost Boys of Sudan" (what is now So. Sudan) and their growing families. Their stories of survival are simultaneously heartbreakingly compelling and amazing. Stories that should
be told again and again.

They are devastated by the destruction that continues to take place in their homeland. A corrupt "central" government and tribal warfare remain a way of life and no one can agree on a solution.

As far as aid goes - The U.S. government should not be writing
checks directly to any of these countries as we know corruption
is rampant. There needs to be a much better organization of how
the foreign aid by us and others is handled so it actually gets to
where it needs to be.

Economically solvent countries need to see the big picture of infra
structure (clean water, waste disposal), regaining the food self sufficiency
people had before decades of conflict, construction of schools and some
decent medical. That was the original intent of the UN but all that has fallen
by the wayside as well. Unfortunately, the U.S. is not going to be very effective
helping these poor nations because we have joined the ranks of those
countries with certifiable crazy dictator "leadership".

I don't have the solutions except to help individually where I can on this side
of the equation. I was a founder of a non-profit (now defunct) to provide educational opps. for the Lost Boys and am now part of another non-profit that works for family enrichment (ESL and other life mentoring activities to assist in acclimating to this culture). It takes a full generation!

At least Bush-Cheney are in the history books, just another one of those right-wing Electoral Junior College hijackings by Republican Machiavellis, incompetents and greedheads that periodically sends America crashing over its proud Caucasian cliffs of ignorance.

America was lucky enough to have a black Abraham Lincoln step up to the plate in 2008 and volunteer to clean up the Republicans' diapers and the accompanying fecal matter they sprayed all across the planet.

We got lucky with Barack Obama.

Will we be lucky again to have someone clean up after the Pre-Schooler-In-Chief, the Know-It-All ignoramus who casually sent Ryan Owens to die in Yemen over dinner, blamed it on 'the generals' and then took credit for it while grotesquely waving his weeping widow in from of a Celebrity Presidential Apprentice audience while psychopathically and sadistically intoning “Ryan is looking down right now, and he’s very happy because, I think, he just broke a (TV applause) record.”

Donald's own 'Mission Accomplished' in Yemen was another smashing deadly and incompetent Republican success...never mind the dead Navy SEAL and his destroyed family....did you see the winning applause meter ?!

Who will save us from this Psychiatric-Patient-In-Chief who's just getting started with his narcissistic wrecking ball, his Kremlin cabinet and Congressional Greed Over People caucus year lusting for the smell of poverty in the morning ?

Stop playing Russian Roulette with your country, American voters.

@socrates, I wonder if he casually sent that Navy Seal Ryan Owen to be killed in action on a failed mission over dinner then saw an opportunity to twist another of his failures around and use it as a prop for one of his rallies or speeches to congress.
This was just another one of his many bankruptcy solutions.

I cringed a bit at the "Black Abraham Lincoln" comment because it took me back to the 2012 campaign and that NY Times expose on a 50-page plan to bring down Obama, the "Black metrosexual Abe Lincoln" or however that group put it.

But you are right that Barack is right up there with Abraham Lincoln. He's definitely the best President of my lifetime and was born during the Kennedy Administration.
All things considered, I cannot but wonder how long this political nightmare called Trumpism can survive. My best guess would less than a year.
By now even his followers understand this principle: there is no bad publicity! it is prima donald's primal tweet

I don't care what Mr. Trump eats as long as he does it out of my sight. Frankly, I don't care what he does for fun (does he ever have any, except hosting rallies?), what music he likes, or where he buys (or sends out for) clothing.

I don't have to care about these things, because I'm more concerned with how his habits are coarsening our culture, dumbing down our civic discourse, ratcheting up the level of fear in this country, destroying humor, and obliterating what passes for truth. And I'm particularly incensed at how he's raised anti-intellectualism to a fine art.

So let the food wags rage, cultural critics obsess over other trivial pursuits of our chief executive. To each his or her own, de gustibus non disputandum est.

Except in one very important circumstance. When a proud, indeed vain man like Trump, lacks the humility to ever admit an error, own a mistake, or take responsibility for anything he says or does, for once, I would dearly love to watch him eat crow.

I kind of care what he does for fun, but only with regard to how much it costs taxpayers. If he were taking a vacation every year and spending the rest of his fun time at the White House playing video games I'd be a lot happier than him taking every weekend off for an expensive golfing trip.
"I would dearly love to watch him eat crow"  ....with ketchup?

Thanks for the heads-up, Deb. As others noted, ALV puzzles, while beloved, don't lend themselves to much blog-worthy chat. I hope the PTB won't confuse the comparatively lower traffic here for low interest in ALV...which for me, is the first thing I do with my Saturday paper delivery, over coffee. Scrubs my brain from the week's overload. I hit the Spelling Bee even before sports or op-ed, which says a lot! And this might be my last chance to have a "private forum" to say: Bring back 3-D Word Hunt! :-) See you on the other side.

I struggle with the fact that the NYT would expose our weaknesses to our enemy, and North Korea IS our enemy.
I have not made up my mind where this article lies between freedom of the press and high treason, but it is not because the NYT can publish this sensitive information, that it should. Furthermore, taking into account the volatile personality personality of our President, to what course will this article lead him ?
Fundamentally, the primary risk of North Korea and Iran is their capability to provide mass fatality bombs to terrorist organizations, without us being able to directly link the source to executant. Eliminating this risk has been one of Obama's failures. Will it also be one of Trump's ?

There are a lot of us who still wish we had that
"weakling" in office -- instead of what's there now.
Ridiculous. They are not a family to abide by any terms. Plus only by presenting a nuclear threat do the family "earn" their right to stay in power.
Good grief.
I was with you until "fake problems." North Korea's ability to annihilate us at the hands of a regime that just may be crazier than Trump himself does not constitute a "trumped up" problem.
Your right luckygal, the NYT needs to do a better job of hiding the truth from us.
Trump and his gang are the worst possible people to deal with this nuclear threat.
Years and years of wishful thinking and weakness from Jimmy Carter to Bill Clinton to Barak Obama has led us to this point.
Easy to point the finger, isn't it? -- But what do base this opinion on, the fact that we're not rattling our sabers, or embroiled in some deadly war???....And are YOU willing to go?
How about Eisenhower? He had the armistice signed and never reached a peace treaty.
Gee, I think you left out GWB!  Oh, that's right!  He was too busy going to war in a non-threatening situation to notice Korea.
When you are dealing with a regime that has brainwashed its people's minds into the belief that their ruler is basically a "god"; good luck with using reason.
